title: Designing Multi-tenant SaaS with Django
excerpt: A deep dive into different multi-tenancy strategies in Django, from shared databases to isolated schemas.
content:
Building a multi-tenant SaaS requires careful planning of how data is isolated between customers. In Django, there are three main approaches:

### 1. Shared Database, Shared Schema
This is the simplest approach where every table has a `tenant_id` column. It's easy to set up but requires strict filtering in every query to prevent data leaks.

### 2. Shared Database, Isolated Schemas (PostgreSQL)
Using PostgreSQL schemas allows you to have separate namespaces for each tenant within the same database. This provides better isolation and easier migrations but adds complexity to the connection handling.

### 3. Isolated Databases
The most secure but also the most expensive and complex to manage. Each tenant gets their own database instance.

For most startups, the **Shared Database, Shared Schema** approach with a robust middleware for filtering is the best balance of speed and scalability.

title: Celery Task Orchestration in Production
excerpt: How to manage complex background jobs, retries, and monitoring in a high-traffic environment.
content:
Celery is a powerful tool, but it can easily become a bottleneck if not configured correctly. Here are my top lessons for running Celery in production:

### 1. Use Multiple Queues
Don't let long-running tasks block critical, fast tasks. Separate your work into `default`, `high-priority`, and `bulk` queues.

### 2. Implement Robust Retries
Network failures happen. Use exponential backoff for retries to avoid overwhelming your services when they come back online.

### 3. Monitor with Flower
Visibility is key. Use Flower to monitor task progress, success rates, and worker health in real-time.

title: Scaling Next.js Dashboards
excerpt: Optimizing performance and user experience in data-heavy administrative interfaces.
content:
Dashboards often become slow as the amount of data grows. Here's how I keep Next.js dashboards snappy:

### 1. Server Components for Initial Load
Leverage React Server Components to fetch data on the server and reduce the amount of JavaScript sent to the client.

### 2. Optimistic Updates
Use SWR or React Query to implement optimistic updates, making the UI feel instantaneous even when the backend is still processing.

### 3. Virtualization for Large Lists
When displaying thousands of rows, use windowing/virtualization to only render what's visible on the screen.

title: Lessons from Rebuilding an ERP Alone
excerpt: The technical and personal challenges of migrating a legacy system to a modern stack single-handedly.
content:
Rebuilding an ERP from scratch is a daunting task, especially as a solo developer. Here's what I learned during the DFCL ERP migration:

### 1. Data Migration is 50% of the Work
Don't underestimate the effort required to clean and move legacy data. Write scripts, test them repeatedly, and have a rollback plan.

### 2. Build a Central API First
By focusing on a robust DRF API first, I was able to build multiple specialized dashboards (Admin, Technician, Customer) without duplicating logic.

### 3. Automate Your Deployments
When you're the only one on call, you need to trust your deployment process. Docker and CI/CD pipelines were lifesavers.
